PUB_0763.comments: Markus Covert visited JVCI in winter 2009. During his visit the JVCI communicated their protocols for culturing M. genitalium including their recipe for SP4 media.

PUB_0764.title: Cell-cycle-regulated expression and subcellular localization of the Caulobacter crescentus SMC chromosome structural protein
PUB_0764.comments:
Philip Goetz emailed Markus Covert on December 10, 2010 with the combination of his latest automatic annotation of the M. genitalium genome and John Glass's latest manual annotation of the genome. The annotation contained a few significant differences from our own:

MG_057: Goetz annotates this gene as ribonuclease MS
MG_505: Goetz annotates this gene as RNase H family
Contains additional conserved hypothetical genes MG_131.1, MG_260.1, and MG_269.1


We chose not to include these additional hypothetical genes in our model, nor the additional 96 hypothetical genes that Phil communicated on February 7, 2011 and March 4, 2011. Current we do not functionally model MG_057 or MG_505.

PUB_0788.title: Transcriptional response of Mycoplasma genitalium to osmotic stress
PUB_0788.comments: Authors developed a new M. genitalium oligo array, and used it to identify the transcriptional response to osmotic stress. The authors found 39 upregulated, and 72 downregulated genes. 21 of the upregulated genes are unannotated and 15 are membrane-associated. This is consistent with the idea that M. genitalium responds to stress by varying its surface component repetoire. Most of the downregulated genes are involved in energy metabolism and translation. OsmC-like protein (MG_454) was downregulated. The authors were unable to explain the molecular mechanism responsible for altered gene expression under osmotic stress.

PUB_0794.title: P110 and P140 cytadherence-related proteins are negative effectors of terminal organelle duplication in Mycoplasma genitalium
PUB_0794.comments: Authors studied regulation of terminal organelle duplication and found that P110 and P140 negatively regulate duplication. The authors showed that P110 and P140 knockouts have greater terminal organelle duplication, but no increased DNA content, suggesting that the terminal organelle does not trigger replication.

PUB_0795.title: Life on arginine for Mycoplasma hominis: clues from its minimal genome and comparison with other human urogenital mycoplasmas
PUB_0795.comments: Authors sequenced M. hominis and compared the genomes of M. genitalium, M. hominis, M. penetrans. The authors identified 247 common genes and hypothesized a theoretical minimum genome containing these 247 plus 9 additional genes required for a mimimal energy metabolism in M. hominis.

PUB_0796.author(s): Lluch-Senar M, Querol E, Piñol J
PUB_0796.title: Cell division in a minimal bacterium in the absence of ftsZ
PUB_0796.comments: Authors constructed a ftsZ null mutant and demonstrated that ftsZ is not required for cell division. In the absence of ftsZ M. genitalium divides using the force generated by motility and its cytoskeleton.

PUB_0797.author(s): Sluijter M, Kaptein E, Spuesens EB, Hoogenboezem T, Hartwig NG, Van Rossum AM, Vink C
PUB_0797.title: The Mycoplasma genitalium MG352-encoded protein is a Holliday junction resolvase that has a non-functional orthologue in Mycoplasma pneumoniae
PUB_0797.comments: Authors show that MG_352 encodes a RecU holliday junction resolvase with activity for holliday junctions. Authors suggest that homologous recombination is critical for antigenic variation in M. genitalium.

PUB_0798.comments: Authors show MG_289, a substrate-binding ABC subunits, has a thiamine binding domain, suggesting it may recognize substrates beyond phosphonate.

PUB_0803.comments: Authors showed that MG_218 and MG_317 knockouts exhibit reduced gliding motility. Additionally they showed that MG_218 encodes two proteins HMW2 and HMW2-s, that the N-terminus of MG_218 is required for proper terminal organelle architecture and that MG_317 is involved in terminal organelle formation and its anchoring to the cell membrane.

PUB_0830.title: Highlights of mycoplasma research--an historical perspective
PUB_0830.comments:
Authors present a history of the study of mycoplasmas 

1898: bovine plueropneumoniae cultivated, mycoplasmas believed to be viruses
1950's -1960's: many believed mycoplasmas were bacterial L-forms or bacteria which had lost their cell walls
1960's-1970's: ultrastructure studied. Morowitz and Wallace argue that Mycoplasma are the most primitive organisms and should be placed at the root of the phylogenetic tree. Neimark proposed that Mycoplasmas originated from walled bacteria. rRNA sequence data confirms Neimark's hypothesis. Maniloff posits that Mycoplasmas arose from the Streptococcus branch 600 million years ago.
Bredt et al show that Mycoplasma replicates by binary fission
Mammalian and insect mollicutes shown to be surface and intracellular parasites
1980's: Morowitz proposes large-scale sequencing effort, but a collaboration never took off; various groups worked independently to map the Mycoplasma genome
1995: TIGR publishes complete sequence of M. genitalium. Herrmann publishes M. pneumoniae sequence shortly thereafter.
1990's: comparatively genomics began, several groups got interested in the minimal gene complement
2000's: JVCI synthesizes Mycoplasma genome
